coverageText:
O gentle youth, that fleetest swift away,  
In vernal bloom dost thou resplendent stand;  
Yet knoweth, like the fleeting light of day,  
Thy vibrant grace ere long shall slip from hand.  

For Time, that ancient thief, doth steal thy cheer,  
With gnawing tread he plucks the tender flower;  
Though now thy visage shines so pure and clear,  
It must by natureâ€™s course be made to sour.  

In thine eye, a spark that sets the heavens alight,  
The flush of spring adorns thy cheeks so fair;  
Yet hark! The bell of age rings in the night,  
To mar thy bloom and write lines of care.  

Shall e'er the golden sun forget to rise,  
Or silver dewdrops cease to kiss the morn?  
No more than these, thy youth's bright paradise  
Shall last, for Time leaves all things worn and torn.  

O fleeting youth, thy sweet morsels savour,  
For e'en in thy prime he forges thy grave;  
In life's ebbing dance, thee must humanly waver,  
Until to the dusty bosom thou art slave.  

Thus let us cherish moments tender and fine,  
Ere aged Winter doth with summer twine;  
For once the vernal days doth draw its line,  
Eternal night claims all that fair doth shine.
